page.title: 20SPYNIE LEGEND LOSSIEMOUTH
page.content: When he arrived at the loch it was covered in thin ice. The ice was thick enough to stop the ferry but too thin to hold a man. After a dispute with the ferryman, Robert told his coachman Alexander Philip to drive across the ice saying, "dinna turn yer heid man or the deil will drown us baith". The coachman scared stiff, his eyes fixed on shore, he daren't breathe. When they were close to shore curiosity took over from fear, the coachman turned his head and saw a monstrous black raven perched on the Laird's shoulder. The raven saw the coachman and flew out of the carriage. At that moment the ice gave way and the carriage sank to its axles. The coachman could never repeat the oath that his master swore.
